ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Produces all optional output.
Specifies arithmetic means for cascading density estimates.

Displays the density and cluster membership of observations with neighbors belonging to a 
different cluster.

[Syntax: CASCADE=n] 
      
Specifies the number of times the density estimates are to be cascaded. The default 
value 0 performs no cascading.

[Syntax: CK=n] 
      
Specifies the number of neighbors to use for clustering. The number of neighbors 
should be at least two but less than the number of observations.

[Syntax: CLUSTER=name] 
      
Provides a name for the variable in the OUT= and OUTCLUS= data sets identifying 
clusters. The default name is CLUSTER.

Keeps the neighbor lists for each observation in the computer memory to make small problems 
run faster.

[Syntax: CR=n] 
      
Specifies the radius of the neighborhood for clustering.

Computes the likelihood cross validation criterion (Silverman 1986, pp. 52–55). 
This option appears to be of limited usefulness.
Displays the cross validated log density of each observation.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the input data set containing observations to be clustered.

[Syntax: DENSITY=name] 
      
Provides a name for the variable in the OUT= data set containing density estimates. 
The default name is DENSITY.

[Syntax: DIMENSION=n] 
      
Specifies the dimensionality to be used when computing density estimates. The default 
is the number of variables if the data are coordinates; the default is 1 if the data 
are distances.

[Syntax: DK=n] 
      
Specifies the number of neighbors to use for th-nearest-neighbor density estimation.

[Syntax: DOCK=n] 
      
Dissolves clusters with n or fewer members by making the members unassigned.

[Syntax: DR=n] 
      
Specifies the radius of the sphere of support for uniform-kernel density estimation.

Stops the cluster analysis after obtaining either a solution with no cluster or a solution 
with one cluster to which all observations are assigned.

Uses harmonic means for cascading density estimates. See the description of the CASCADE= option 
for details.

[Syntax: K=n] 
      
Specifies the number of neighbors to use for th-nearest-neighbor density estimation 
and clustering.

[Syntax: JOIN<=p>] 
        
Requests that nonsignificant clusters be hierarchically joined. The JOIN option 
implies the TEST option.
Displays the estimated density and cluster membership of each observation.
Requests estimates of local dimensionality.

[Syntax: MAXCLUSTERS=n] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of clusters to be obtained with the METHOD=6 option. 
By default, there is no fixed limit.

Specifies what clustering method to use. Since these methods do not have widely recognized names, 
the methods are indicated by numbers from 0 to 6.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: This method does not use density estimates.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: This method is similar to the classification or assignment stage of algorithms described by Gitman (1973) and Huizinga (1978).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: This method is similar to the first stage of an algorithm proposed by Mizoguchi and Shimura (1980).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: This method was invented by Koontz, Narendra, and Fukunaga (1976).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: This method is equivalent to the first stage of two-stage density linkage without the use of the MODE=option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: This method is equivalent to the first stage of two-stage density linkage with the use of the MODE=option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: This method is related to a method invented by Koontz and Fukunaga (1972a) and discussed by Koontz and Fukunaga (1972b).

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MODE=n] 
      
Specifies that when two clusters are joined using the METHOD=5 option (no other 
methods are affected by the MODE= option), each must have at least n members for 
either cluster to be designated a modal cluster.
Displays the neighbors of each observation in a table called "Nearest Neighbor List."
Suppresses the display of the output.

Suppresses the display of the summary of the number of clusters, number of unassigned observations, 
and maximum -value for each analysis.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the output data set containing the input data plus density estimates, 
cluster membership, and variables identifying the type of solution.

[Syntax: OUTCLUS=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the output data set containing an observation corresponding to each 
cluster in each solution.

[Syntax: OUTSUM=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the output data set containing an observation corresponding to each 
cluster solution, giving the number of clusters and the number of unclassified 
observations for that solution.

[Syntax: OUTLENGTH=n] 
      
Specifies the length of those output variables that are not copied from the 
input data set but are created by PROC MODECLUS.

[Syntax: POWER=n] 
      
Specifies the power of the density used with the METHOD=6 option. The default value is 2.

[Syntax: R=n] 
      
Specifies the radius of the sphere of support for uniform-kernel density estimation 
and the neighborhood for clustering.
Suppresses the display of statistics for each cluster.

Displays means, standard deviations, skewness, kurtosis, and a coefficient of bimodality. 
The SIMPLE option applies only to coordinate data.

Standardizes the variables to mean 0 and standard deviation 1. The STANDARD option applies 
only to coordinate data.
Uses sums for cascading density estimates.
Performs approximate significance tests for the number of clusters.

[Syntax: THRESHOLD=n] 
      
Specifies the assignment threshold used with the METHOD=6 option. The default is 0.5.
Traces the process of cluster assignments when METHOD=6 is specified.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
You can specify a BY statement with PROC MODECLUS to obtain separate analyses on 
observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement 
appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY 
variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified 
is used.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FREQ variable;
      
If one variable in the input data set represents the frequency of occurrence for other values 
in the observation, specify the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. PROC MODECLUS then treats 
the data set as if each observation appeared n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable 
for the observation.

Syntax: ID variables ; 
    
The values of the ID variable identify observations in the displayed results and in the OUT= data set. 
If you omit the ID statement, each observation is identified by its observation number, and a variable
called _OBS_ is written to the OUT= data set containing the original observation numbers.
